articles.headline: Protests Widen as Brazilians Chide Leaders
articles.snippet: Demonstrators remained defiant Tuesday, pouring into the streets by the thousands and venting their anger over political corruption, the high cost of living and huge public spending for the World Cup and the Olympics.
articles.abstract: Demonstrators remained defiant Tuesday, pouring into the streets by the thousands and venting their anger over political corruption, the high cost of living and huge public spending for the World Cup and the Olympics.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Shaken by the biggest challenge to their authority in years, Brazil’s leaders made conciliatory gestures on Tuesday to try to defuse the protests engulfing the nation’s cities. But the demonstrators remained defiant, pouring into the streets by the thousands and venting their anger over political corruption, the high cost of living and huge public spending for the World Cup and the Olympics.

articles.headline: As Coney Island Stirs, One Man’s Vision Is Unbuilt
articles.snippet: Horace Bullard had big plans for redeveloping the Coney Island of his youth, but he died with his properties still on the market.
articles.abstract: Horace Bullard had big plans for redeveloping the Coney Island of his youth, but he died with his properties still on the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: For over 30 years, Horace Bullard’s visions for Coney Island amounted to little more than a boardwalk of broken dreams.

articles.headline: Making the Case for a Rise in Inflation
articles.snippet: Some economists are arguing for inflation above the long-favored 2 percent limit, as a way to jump-start the economy.
articles.abstract: Some economists are arguing for inflation above the long-favored 2 percent limit, as a way to jump-start the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: I was in Brazil in the early 1990s, when annual inflation topped 2,000 percent and Brazilians spent their entire paychecks as soon as they got them, buying a month’s worth of food and other supplies before their money lost most of its value. When I moved there a few years later, inflation had been “tamed” to some 16 percent. But you couldn’t buy oranges at the supermarket in packages of less than 20 pounds.

articles.headline: A.M.A. Recognizes Obesity as a Disease
articles.snippet: The decision by the American Medical Association could have implications for health care companies and the pharmaceutical industry.
articles.abstract: The decision by the American Medical Association could have implications for health care companies and the pharmaceutical industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American Medical Association has officially recognized obesity as a disease, a move that could induce physicians to pay more attention to the condition and spur more insurers to pay for treatments.

articles.headline: Uncertainty at Fed Over Its Stimulus Plans and Its Leadership
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke faces the growing challenge of shaping investor expectations amid increasing signs that his era as Federal Reserve chairman is ending.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke faces the growing challenge of shaping investor expectations amid increasing signs that his era as Federal Reserve chairman is ending.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, faces the increasingly difficult challenge of shaping investor expectations about the future course of Fed policy amid growing signs that the Bernanke era at the central bank is drawing to a close.

articles.headline: Nickelodeon Resists Critics of Food Ads
articles.snippet: In resisting calls to ban ads for nutritionally questionable food, Nickelodeon argued that its job was children’s entertainment, not nutrition.
articles.abstract: In resisting calls to ban ads for nutritionally questionable food, Nickelodeon argued that its job was children’s entertainment, not nutrition.
articles.lead_paragraph: One year ago, the Walt Disney Company unveiled a strict new set of nutritional standards and said it would ban ads for noncompliant foods from its child-focused cable channels by 2015. Advocacy groups fighting childhood obesity cheered.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Extending a Hand, Obama Finds a Cold Shoulder Abroad
articles.snippet: President Obama’s main counterparts on the world stage make little attempt to cloak their disagreements in diplomatic niceties.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s main counterparts on the world stage make little attempt to cloak their disagreements in diplomatic niceties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over porterhouse steak and cherry pie at a desert estate in California earlier this month, President Obama delivered a stern lecture to President Xi Jinping about China’s disputes with its neighbors. If it is going to be a rising power, he scolded, it needs to behave like one.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Peter Baker

articles.headline: In Bulger’s Underworld, a ‘Judas Was the Worst’
articles.snippet: In early testimony in the criminal trial of James (Whitey) Bulger, who is charged with racketeering and murder, witnesses shared their concepts of honor and loyalty.
articles.abstract: In early testimony in the criminal trial of James (Whitey) Bulger, who is charged with racketeering and murder, witnesses shared their concepts of honor and loyalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — “Family and friends come first,” John Martorano, an aging gangster known as the Executioner, declared from the witness stand here on Tuesday. “My father always taught me that. The priests and the nuns I grew up with taught me that. They taught me that Judas — Judas was the worst person in the world.”

articles.headline: The F.B.I. Deemed Agents Faultless in 150 Shootings
articles.snippet: Critics say the fact that no agent in the past two decades has been disciplined for deliberately shooting someone raises questions about the bureau’s internal investigations.
articles.abstract: Critics say the fact that no agent in the past two decades has been disciplined for deliberately shooting someone raises questions about the bureau’s internal investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After contradictory stories emerged about an F.B.I. agent’s killing last month of a Chechen man in Orlando, Fla., who was being questioned over ties to the Boston Marathon bombing suspects, the bureau reassured the public that it would clear up the murky episode.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: 3-D Printers to Make Things You Need or Like
articles.snippet: 3-D printing seems like an exciting new technology, but practical applications of the technology are harder to come by.
articles.abstract: 3-D printing seems like an exciting new technology, but practical applications of the technology are harder to come by.
articles.lead_paragraph: You may have seen some odd-shaped plastic trinkets on someone’s desk or heard about the first shots fired a few weeks ago from a 3-D printed gun. With every new 3-D printed object, the world seems to be getting closer to a future where we can “print out” objects like furniture, clothing, human tissue and even buildings. NASA even recently invested in technology to print food. The possibilites are staggering.
